data.label:
Narrator

It was early evening, still light out with just a faint nip in the air. Franc was at a friend's and Deana was at an art class. Monica and I decided to go out for a walk before dinner.

Narrator

Monica met me by the door, and we put on our coats and hats.

Monica

“One way or another, I want to contribute to this country. No matter what happens.”

Monica

“Let’s get back to the house for dinner."

Narrator

What did our ideals really mean if they could be changed so easily? What about the people we idolize?

Narrator

Ionas had once fought hard and strong against Soll’s judiciary reforms. But after years of the government blocking his every move, he gave up on his ideals and became a part of the administration.

Monica

“Otherwise, we will end up like...”

Monica Guess Hub

Monica Guess Hub

Monica

“Guess again.”

Narrator

At that moment, we passed Ionas Crona again. He was on a nearby bench, taking a smoke break after his own walk. Monica plastered on a big smile and greeted him, then turned back to me.

Monica

“...Spineless.”

Narrator

If that was how people remembered Ionas, how would they remember me? Whatever he had done, whatever ideals he had lost, he must have had his reasons.

Player

“Of course. Lead the way.”

Narrator

I was just starting to understand the meaning of those words.

Narrator

The sun began to set over the horizon, bathing the clouds in shades of orange and pink.

Monica

“So, how was your day?”

Player

“Paperwork, endless meetings... the usual nightmare.”

Monica

"I don't know. I imagine some might find that stimulating."

Monica

"Avoiding my question, are we? Very well.”

Monica

"Evelyn also came round for tea. She says hi. She was feeling rather low, though. Apparently she and Petr had a bit of a disagreement."

Monica

“Apparently Petr had too much whiskey -- as usual -- and didn't behave when Evelyn's father was over for dinner yesterday.”

Monica

“I hope so. They always seemed so close.”

Player

“That's Petr -- perpetually pickled. I'll have a talk with him.”

Player

“To be honest, I don't care."

Player

“Who?”

Narrator

Neither the name nor the description rang a bell.

Player

“I still don't remember her, but go on."

Player

“So what?”

Monica

“I know, I was beside myself when she told me. And that's not all.”

Player

“So she called the First Lady to ask for help?"

Player

“That doesn't solve the deeper problem, though."

Monica

“I know that the mayor of Anrica, Curtan Leste, will be delivering a speech at the annual opening of the Benfi festival.“

Monica

“I want our voice heard, and this festival is the time to do it. I just need your blessing as my husband and the President of Sordland.“

Player

“You have my full support. Always.”

Player

“Absolutely not. Out of the question.”

Player

“Sure, it's just a speech. What's the worst that can happen?”

Player

“I don't want you to step into politics.”

Player

“It's not the right time. Sordland is facing too much political strife -- we'll have to deal with women's rights later.”

Monica

"I won't let you down, Anton. Thank you.“

Narrator

Monica was silent for a while. When she finally spoke, there was a chill in her voice.

Player

“Sorry, but I can't make Curtan Leste angry."

Monica

“My wish is to take his place and deliver the speech instead."

Monica

“It's not just a speech -- it's an opportunity for real change. An end to centuries of oppression, and the beginning of a more equal society.“

Monica

“I don't understand. Isn't this something you care about as well?"

Monica

"Women in this country are still seen as wives and mothers first, human beings second.”

Monica

“I know I'm not experienced. But I can do this. You have to trust me!“

Player

“My word is final. You will not make the speech.”

Monica

“I want to base the speech on women's rights in Sordland. On the oppression and discrimination we face everyday, on the basis of our sex alone."

Narrator

Monica's eyes were blazing with a fire I hadn't seen since we were students. She wanted this badly.

Player

"I hope yours was better?"

Monica

“You know Petr. What do you think of this?”

Monica

“Good. Evelyn seemed close to tears.”

Monica

“Maybe you should. He's your vice president after all. And they're our closest friends.”

Monica

"A few years younger than me, red hair, scar on her forehead? We had dinner with her and her husband once or twice."

Player_Italic

"Of course. I'll lead the way."

Player

“What's she nagging him about this time?"

Monica

“You know Evelyn hasn't been the same since what happened to her at Holsord Post last year.”

Player

“Maybe he didn't try hard enough.”

Player

“She had it coming.”

Player

“A sad day for journalism and free speech in Sordland.”

Monica

"How can you say that? It was a sad day for freedom of the press in Sordland."

Monica

“I don't think anything would have worked. It was a sad day for freedom of the press in Sordland.”

Monica

“I completely agree. A sad day indeed.”

Player

“Look at it from a cost standpoint. Obviously, they don't want to lose money.”

Player_Italic

I kept walking.

Monica

“They're harassed at work, underpaid, blocked from positions of power... and those are the lucky ones!"

Player

“I'm sure the parents have their reasons.”

Monica

“These backwards ideals are slowing down Sordland's transformation into a modern nation.”

Monica

“Which brings me to my point.“

Monica

“These little girls and people like Janice need someone to speak on their behalf. A role model. A successful woman.“

Monica

"It can't just be you. These little girls and people like Janice need someone to speak on their behalf. A role model. A successful woman.“

Player

“Nonsense. We have our guards -- there's nothing to be afraid of. Let's go to Capitol Park.”

Monica

“I was going to suggest we walk towards Soll Square, but the guards told me it's been closed for yet another protest.”

Player

“Common thugs. I will make sure they are punished.”

Player

“Must be those damn communists again.”

Player

“The Young Sords are taking it too far.”

Monica

“In any case, where shall we go? I'm not sure Capitol Park is a wise idea in this climate, either...

Player

“You're right -- it's not worth the security risk. Let's stay inside the gates.”

Narrator

Our favorite place for a stroll was the nearby Capitol Park, the largest green space in all of Holsord. Before the children were born, we had spent many an evening engaged in deep conversation along the riverside promenade.

Monica

“All right. Let's go, then, before the children get home.”

Narrator

The guards followed at a discreet distance as we headed towards the walking trail.

Narrator

As we entered the park, Monica broke the silence.

Monica

“I was going to suggest we walk towards Soll Square, but the guards told me it's been closed because of the emergency act.”

Monica

“So you say. But I still don't like seeing so many guns on the streets.”

Player

“I know. It's unnerving to me too.”

Narrator

Leste was one of Sordland's most influential politicians. He had started his career in Benfi before rising to power in Anrica. Benfi's current mayor had personally invited him to make the opening speech.

Narrator

When we arrived home, I called my secretary Livia and asked her to inform Mr. Leste that Monica would be making the speech in his stead.

Monica

"You were a damn communist yourself, once upon a time."

Monica

"You were one of those thugs yourself, once upon a time."

Player

"This is different. A nastier breed."

Player

"I was young and stupid. I didn't know any better."

Monica

"Old grudges die hard, I see."

Monica

"The Anton I knew in university never would have said that."

Player

"Funny how becoming president changes one's perspective."

Player

"Aren't you glad you and I don't have these kinds of quarrels?"

Narrator

Monica gave me a quick kiss on the cheek. We continued walking.

Narrator

Monica didn't say anything. We kept walking.

Narrator

Monica gave me a sharp look. We kept walking.

Player

“Can't her husband provide for the both of them while she raises the child?"

Monica

"Exactly! I knew you'd be on the same page."

Monica

"Really, Anton? After everything we've talked about?"

Narrator

We had reached the pond at the end of the trail. A park bench overlooked the water. Monica gestured to it, and we sat down.

Player

“Does it have to be at the festival? Why can't you make your speech another time?"

Monica

“It has to be now. Thousands go to this festival, and millions watch the speeches at home. Sordland's women can't wait any longer!“

Narrator

Just outside the gate, I glimpsed Ionas Crona, the former Minister of Justice, walking towards Capitol Park. I remembered that Nia Morgna used to be his Vice Minister. He didn't seem to notice us as he walked by.

Narrator

Monica smiled.

Monica

"You know, I believe I will."

Player

"For a good reason."

Narrator

It was early evening, still light out with just a faint nip in the air. Franc was at a friend's and Deana was at an art class. Monica and I decided to go out for a walk before dinner.

Narrator

It was early evening, still light out with just a faint nip in the air. Franc was at a friend's and Deana was at an art class. Monica and I decided to go out for a walk before dinner.

Monica

“Remember my time with the Sordish League of Women in university? You supported me then. I'm asking you to support me now.“
